citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
* One 100 CC bottle of Excede was observed in the refrigerator in the whelp building. Review of medical records did not
list Excede as an approved antibiotic to be used on the dogs. There was no labeling on the Excede bottle from the
attending veterinarian to show this antibiotic was approved for use on the dogs. Applicant stated that they could not
remember the last time this antibiotic was administrated to the dogs. Usage of any drug without attending veterinarian
approval does not ensure it is the correct antibiotic for treatment, is being given at the proper dosage rate and that it is
being administrated correctly. This could lead to failure to provide measures for prevention, control, and treatment of
disease. The applicant must ensure that all drugs are used in a manner consistent with the provision of adequate
veterinary care to protect the health of the animals and ensure drugs are used in an appropriate manner. The applicant
shall establish and maintain a program of adequate veterinary care that include appropriate methods to prevent, control,
diagnose, and treat diseases.

* The applicant had incomplete records showing how many dogs had been heartworm and fecal float tested and the date
both tests were conducted. The applicant stated that both had been completed but could not produce documentation to
verify the number of dogs or the date that the testing took place.. Fecal float and Heartworm testing are done to ensure
that there are no active internal parasites or worms. Copies of the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or
other required or recommended tests must be maintained by the applicant as part of the required medical records.
Documentation of all required tests must be made available to APHIS inspectors upon request.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class A license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 5, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
* One 100 CC bottle of Excede was observed in the refrigerator in the whelp building. Review of medical records did not 
list Excede as an approved antibiotic to be used on the dogs. There was no labeling on the Excede bottle from the 
attending veterinarian to show this antibiotic was approved for use on the dogs. Applicant stated that they could not 
remember the last time this antibiotic was administrated to the dogs. Usage of any drug without attending veterinarian 
approval does not ensure it is the correct antibiotic for treatment, is being given at the proper dosage rate and that it is 
being administrated correctly. This could lead to failure to provide measures for prevention, control, and treatment of 
disease. The applicant must ensure that all drugs are used in a manner consistent with the provision of adequate 
veterinary care to protect the health of the animals and ensure drugs are used in an appropriate manner. The applicant 
shall establish and maintain a program of adequate veterinary care that include appropriate methods to prevent, control, 
diagnose, and treat diseases. 
3.13(b)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The applicant had incomplete records showing how many dogs had been heartworm and fecal float tested and the date 
both tests were conducted. The applicant stated that both had been completed but could not produce documentation to 
verify the number of dogs or the date that the testing took place.. Fecal float and Heartworm testing are done to ensure 
that there are no active internal parasites or worms. Copies of the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or 
other required or recommended tests must be maintained by the applicant as part of the required medical records. 
Documentation of all required tests must be made available to APHIS inspectors upon request. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class A license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 5, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

n
